awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a modern single-crystal X-ray diffractometer with a high dynamic range detector
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Instrumentation Programs. Professor Ilia Guzei from the University of Wisconsin-Madison and colleagues are acquiring a single crystal diffractometer equipped with a sensitive wide-field detector system and a copper source. In general, an X-ray diffractometer (XRD) allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles.  XRD also provides accurate information about the spatial arrangements of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. The X-ray laboratory personnel utilize the diffractometer to foster an inclusive climate for underrepresented minority, low-income, and/or first-generation graduate students. In addition, the laboratory plays an important role in strengthening the relationship between the University and Wisconsin citizens through an outreach program for middle and high school students and by working closely with other programs advocating the importance of science, research, and education to the public.

The award of the X-ray diffractometer is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution. The instrument acquisition award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. The XRD will impact research areas involving the development of catalysts for aerobic oxidation and the characterization of molecules and proteins that wrap around themselves, commonly called foldamers. It is also used in studies aimed at decoding bacterial communication and for carrying out enantioselective photocatalysis. The diffractometer is used in engineering biocatalysts, characterizing transition metal compounds, and understanding the structure and function of bioactive molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In December 2019 the Molecular Structure Laboratory of the University of Wisconsin–Madison Chemistry Department commissioned a new state-of-the-art single-crystal X-ray diffractometer supported by this grant from the NSF. The University of Wisconsin–Madison shared the cost of the purchase. The instrument chosen was a Bruker D8 VENTURE Photon III with a single copper X-ray radiation source. This carefully selected and thoroughly tested diffractometer provides strong research support to a broad community of high scientific caliber, is used regularly for graduate and undergraduate teaching, and is showcased during graduate student recruiting. It is the first diffractometer in the laboratory to be extensively governed remotely and it found important applications in our outreach projects involving WI universities and the general community.

The new Bruker D8 VENTURE Photon III has become a core resource for scientists engaged in vibrant chemistry research programs. More than 20 research groups from UW–Madison, surrounding areas, and international academic institutions have had their samples characterized on the new instrument. Researchers and graduate students have been able to access and operate the instrument remotely, which was a critical component of conducting structural investigations during the pandemic. Additionally, the availability of a cutting-edge diffractometer is vital to attracting world-class faculty and it contributes to our pursuit to change the department demographic and increase the number of women faculty to at least 30%.

The diffractometer has enhanced the critical research infrastructure by providing new technical capabilities to all collaborators, both internal and external. The welcome experimental advancements include the following. It is now possible to characterize very thin, small, micron-scale crystals – such experiments would not have been possible without this instrument. The new capability of acquiring publishable quality data on macromolecular targets has expanded the range of the samples submitted to the laboratory and increased the number of our collaborators. Rapid acquisition of high-quality data has been particularly important for challenging crystals that are not stable under ambient conditions or deteriorate in the X-ray beam. Additionally, researchers may receive answers to their questions faster, which accelerates progress on their projects. We have also performed many multi-day polymorphic investigations of light-sensitive crystals and powder samples, analyses that were not available elsewhere on campus. The results generated with this diffractometer have been used in research of catalytic reactions of redox cycles, natural product synthesis, drug compound screening libraries, development of chiral catalysts for photochemical reactions, design of foldamers with structure and function resembling those of proteins, chiral product characterization, polymorphism of drug molecules, strategies and methods of generation of drug-like heterocyclic compounds, and studies of antibacterial compounds.

One of the longest and deepest traditions at the University of Wisconsin is the “Wisconsin Idea”: the benefits of the university should be made manifest beyond the university itself, throughout the entire state of Wisconsin. We make our research facilities available to other users in our geographic region. The X-ray laboratory maintains strong collaborations with primarily undergraduate institutions with diverse student populations including other UW campuses at La Crosse, Platteville, Stevens Point, and Whitewater.

X-Ray crystallography features heavily in our educational mission and our pedagogical model is designed to promote independent thinking. Single-crystal X-ray analysis is the premiere analytical technique for structure determination and therefore underlies much of the chemical content of our undergraduate and graduate courses. The new instrument has made crystallography more accessible to scientists who can use this method to answer scientific questions and has helped students solidify their understanding of chemistry and physics concepts. Remote access expanded the training opportunities for young scientists who could interact with the complex instrument either in person or while off-campus. The diffractometer has been extensively utilized in a 600-level graduate course and for a multifaceted undergraduate research project thereby improving graduate and undergraduate learning. Young scientists who use crystallographic results acquire a necessary skill that increases their competency and allows them to become more competitive in the workforce. Students who have obtained data on the new diffractometer have been primary authors or co-authors of over 20 publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference poster presentations.

The acquisition of the diffractometer has directly and indirectly contributed to the breadth of diverse research and educational activities within the Department of Chemistry at UW–Madison. Above all, the instrument has enhanced critical research infrastructure by providing new technical capabilities. Access to the new state-of-the-art instrument has positively influenced experimentation across all research areas and student groups by providing new opportunities to internal and external collaborators. With the new diffractometer the X-ray lab users are better able to engage in a wider range of projects. The X-ray laboratory has been a dedicated advocate of chemistry education within and beyond the walls of the Chemistry Department and the proposed instrument has amplified the outcome of these activities.
